Title: Who was Saleh al-Arouri, the Hamas leader killed in Beirut?
Subtitle: Killing of the deputy chief of Hamasâ€™s political bureau could spark retaliation from Hamas and Hezbollah.
Content: A drone strike in Beirutâ€™s southern suburbs of Dahiyeh, a Hezbollah stronghold, killed senior Hamas official Saleh al-Arouri on Tuesday. The drone hit a Hamas office, leaving six people dead, Lebanonâ€™s state news agency reported. Hamas confirmed the death of al-Arouri and called it a â€œcowardly assassinationâ€ by Israel, adding that attacks on Palestinians â€œinside and outside Palestine will not succeed in breaking the will and steadfastness of our people, or undermining the continuation of their valiant resistanceâ€. â€œIt proves once again the abject failure of this enemy to achieve any of its aggressive goals in the Gaza Strip,â€ the group said. Following the news of the death of al-Arouri, mosques in Arura, the occupied West Bank town of north Ramallah, are mourning his death and a general strike has been called in Ramallah for Wednesday. Here is what to know about the Hamas official killed in Lebanon. Al-Arouri, 57, was the deputy chief of Hamasâ€™s political bureau and one of the founders of the groupâ€™s armed wing, the Qassam Brigades. He had been living in exile in Lebanon after spending 15 years in an Israeli jail. Before the war began on October 7, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu had threatened to kill him. In recent weeks, al-Arouri took on the role of spokesperson for the group and told Al Jazeera last month that Hamas would not discuss an exchange deal for the captives the group is holding before the war ends in Gaza. The United States labelled al-Arouri as a â€œglobal terroristâ€ in 2015 and issued a $5m reward for any information on him. While there has been no official response from Israel about the death of the Hamas official, Mark Regev, an adviser to Netanyahu, told the US outlet MSNBC that Israel does not take responsibility for this attack. But, added, â€œWhoever did it, it must be clear: this was not an attack on the Lebanese state.â€ â€œWhoever did this did a surgical strike against the Hamas leadership,â€ he said. However, Danny Danon, a former Israeli envoy to the United Nations, hailed the attack and congratulated the Israeli army, Shin Bet, the security service and Mossad, Israelâ€™s intelligence agency, for killing al-Arouri. â€œAnyone who was involved in the 7/10 massacre should know that we will reach out to them and close an account with them,â€ he said on X in Hebrew, referring to the October 7 Hamas attack on southern Israel that killed nearly 1,200 people. Israelâ€™s relentless bombing and artillery shelling of Gaza since then has killed more than 22,000 Palestinians, including more than 8,000 children. According to Israeli media, the government has ordered cabinet ministers not to give any interviews about al-Arouriâ€™s death after Danonâ€™s tweet. Lebanonâ€™s caretaker Prime Minister Najib Mikati condemned the attack on the Beruit suburb and said it was a â€œnew Israeli crimeâ€ as well as an attempt to pull Lebanon into the war. Mikati also warned against the â€œIsraeli political upper echelon resorting to exporting its failures in Gaza to the southern border to impose new facts on the ground and change the rules of engagementâ€. Hezbollah said that the attack on Lebanonâ€™s capital â€œwill not pass without punishmentâ€.

Title: Biden under pressure to act amid new fears of â€˜ethnic cleansingâ€™ in Gaza
Subtitle: Remarks from far-right ministers renew concerns that Israel aims to force Palestinians out of Gaza amid ongoing war.
Content: Rights advocates in the United States are urging President Joe Biden to end his administrationâ€™s â€œcomplicityâ€ in Israeli rights abuses after key members of Israelâ€™s government backed the idea of pushing Palestinians out of Gaza. Far-right Israeli ministersItamar Ben-Gvirand Bezalel Smotrich said this week that Israel should â€œencourage emigrationâ€ from the coastal enclave, home to an estimated 2.3 million Palestinians. Israel has been carrying out a military offensive in Gaza since October 7, resulting in an estimated 1.9 million Palestinians being internally displaced, according to the United Nations. â€œIf there are 100,000 or 200,000 Arabs in Gaza and not two million Arabs, the entire discussion on the day after [the war ends] will be totally different,â€Smotrich saidon Sunday, calling for the â€œvoluntary migrationâ€ of Palestinians. A day later, Ben-Gvir, who oversees national security, made a similar appeal, saying it was â€œa correct, just, moral and humane solutionâ€, Israeli media outlets reported. Their remarks are the latest by Israeli officials alluding to the prospect of resettling Palestinians outside of Gaza. Human rights and legal experts have warned that forced displacement constitutes a war crime under international law andcould leadto ethnic cleansing. â€œItâ€™s not really â€˜voluntaryâ€™ when youâ€™re bombing homes and starving the entire population,â€ said Rasha Mubarak, a Palestinian American organiser. Mubarak told Al Jazeera that the Biden administration has not only failed to condemn Israeli officialsâ€™ push to get Palestinians out of Gaza, but it has also contributed to the war by providing Israel with continued military aid and diplomatic support. â€œThey have played an immense part in this genocide and ethnic cleansing of the Palestinian people,â€ she said.    Over the past several weeks, asIsrael pressed onwith its bombing campaign, senior US officials have said they do not support efforts to force Palestinians out of the enclave. â€œThe United States remains firmly opposed to any forced or enduring displacement of Palestinians from Gaza,â€ a State Department spokesperson told Al Jazeera in an email on Monday evening, without commenting specifically on the Israeli ministersâ€™ most recent remarks. In a statement on Tuesday afternoon, State Department spokesman Matthew Miller said Washington â€œrejectsâ€ the comments by Ben-Gvir and Smotrich. â€œThis rhetoric is inflammatory and irresponsible. We have been told repeatedly and consistently by the Government of Israel, including by the Prime Minister, that such statements do not reflect the policy of the Israeli government. They should stop immediately,â€ Miller said. But rights advocates say the USâ€™s unwavering support for Israelâ€™s war, which has killed more than 22,000 Palestinians in Gaza to date, is leaving the door open to further atrocities and violations of international law. Under theFourth Geneva Convention, civilians cannot be deported or forcibly transferred from a territory unless such a move is required for â€œthe security of civilians involved or imperative military reasonsâ€. The International Criminal Court (ICC) also states that the forcible displacement of civilians is a war crime unless justified by â€œmilitary necessityâ€ or civilian safety. Kenneth Roth, a former head of Human Rights Watch, told Al Jazeera in a television interview on Monday that the â€œidea of massive ethnic cleansing â€” the war crime of forced displacement â€” is still very much an ideaâ€ within Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahuâ€™s government.    Critics fear, however, that there is growing pressure to make that idea a reality in Gaza. Ben-Gvirâ€™s and Smotrichâ€™s comments are only the latest in a string of comments that have prompted concern since the war began. In late October, for instance, the news outlet +972 Magazine reported that the Israeli Ministry of Intelligence had recommended the forcible transfer of Gazaâ€™s population to Egyptâ€™s Sinai Peninsula. Intelligence Minister Gila Gamliel, a member of Netanyahuâ€™s Likud Party, also wrote in The Jerusalem Post in November that the international community should be â€œhelping the people of Gaza build new livesâ€ elsewhere. Danny Danon, Israelâ€™s former ambassador to the UN and another Likud lawmaker, also has promoted the â€œvoluntary migrationâ€ idea. In a Wall Street Journal opinion column in November, Danon and Yesh Atid party legislator Ram Ben-Barak urged â€œa handful of the worldâ€™s nations to share the responsibility of hosting Gazan residentsâ€. Yet while the US has pressed Israeli leaders to avoid civilian casualties and allow more humanitarian aid into Gaza, Roth said that â€œBiden so far refuses to use the leverage he hasâ€ to pressure Israel. The country receives $3.8bn in US military aid annually. In addition, late last week, the Biden administrationbypassedCongress to authorise the transfer of about $147m in artillery ammunition,sayingthat â€œan emergency exists that requires the immediate saleâ€ of the weapons to Israel. â€œIt would have been very simple to say, â€˜You want these weapons? Let in the aid. You want these weapons? Stop killing so many civilians.â€™ [Biden] didnâ€™t do that,â€ Roth said. â€œHe left it completely unconditional, giving up the leverage he had and, in a sense, making him complicit in whatâ€™s going on â€” actually, an aider and abetter of those war crimes.â€    Zaha Hassan, a human rights lawyer and fellow at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, also told Al Jazeera that the Biden administration could be doing more to discourage any attempts at forced displacement. Israelâ€™s military offensive, she explained, has â€œmade Gaza not just unlivable but has put at risk the lives of the 2.3 million Palestinians that are thereâ€. Israel â€” asan occupying powerâ€” has an obligation to ensure the basic needs of Gazaâ€™s Palestinians are met, Hassan said. But instead, the ongoing Israeli bombardment has destroyed critical infrastructure in Gaza, and its siege is severely limiting access to food, water and other much-needed supplies. â€œSo to come now and say that Palestinians in Gaza, if they so chose to leave, would be welcome to do so by Israel is a really cynical understanding of their obligations. They havenâ€™t really created choice at this point for Palestinians. Theyâ€™re trying to, it appears, force them to flee and force them to seek safety and survival elsewhere,â€ she said. Hassan also calledNetanyahuâ€™s commentsabout taking control of the Egypt-Gaza border zone â€” an area known asthe Philadelphi corridorâ€” deeply concerning. â€œThis would enable them to execute on any plans they have to push Palestinians out of Gaza under this guise of it being voluntary.â€ Voluntary migration? No matter how ISR gvt calls it, Forced Displacement is a CRIME, prosecutable under the Rome Statute.Its architects shall be investigated/prosecuted by@IntlCrimCourt& other courts under#UniversalJurisdiction.@KarimKhanQC: Justice delayed is Justice denied.https://t.co/TTfvHxIYot â€” Francesca Albanese, UN Special Rapporteur oPt (@FranceskAlbs)December 26, 2023  While officials have said the Biden administration does not support forced displacement, â€œwe havenâ€™t seen much in the way of US action to prevent all of the different ways in which Israel is making displacement inevitableâ€, Hassan said. â€œWe havenâ€™t heard US officials say it is absolutely illegitimate and illegal to starve a population â€” to deny them food, water, electricity and utilities and supplies,â€ she said. â€œThe US has a lot of influence over Israel. It has not so far been willing to do more than have quiet conversations with Israel behind the scenes about what it expects. It has of late made some statements publicly, but we havenâ€™t seen it use its leverage as it would need to.â€ Smotrichâ€™s and Ben-Gvirâ€™s statements, however, have renewed pressure for the US to act. Nihad Awad, executive director of the Council on American-Islamic Relations (CAIR), released astatementon Sunday calling on the Biden administration to â€œrepudiateâ€ Smotrichâ€™s words. He added that US leaders â€œmust finally acknowledge what has long been known and demonstrated daily by Israelâ€™s genocidal actions â€” that Israelâ€™s racist government seeks to ethnically cleanse Gazaâ€. â€œIt has always been the Israeli governmentâ€™s plan to ethnically cleanse Gaza,â€ he wrote. â€œSmotrich just made it official.â€

Title: Senior Hamas official Saleh al-Arouri killed in Beirut suburb
Subtitle: At least six people killed in Israeli drone strike on Lebanese capital, state media report.
Content: Senior Hamas official Saleh al-Arouri has been killed in an Israeli drone strike on Beirutâ€™s southern suburb of Dahiyeh, the Palestinian group and Lebanese media outlets say. Al-Arouri was killed on Tuesday in a â€œtreacherous Zionist strikeâ€, Hamas said on its official channel. Hamas politburo member Izzat al-Sharq called it a â€œcowardly assassinationâ€. Al-Arouri was a senior official in Hamasâ€™s politburo and was known to be deeply involved in its military affairs. He had previously headed the groupâ€™s presence in the occupied West Bank. Samir Findi Abu Amer and Azzam Al-Aqraa Abu Ammar, leaders of Hamasâ€™ armed wing â€“ the Qassam Brigades â€“ were also killed, Hamas said in a message on its Telegram channel. It named four other members of the group who were also killed. Earlier, Lebanonâ€™s state-run National News Agency said the blast killed at least six people and that it was carried out by an Israeli drone. Hamas said al-Arouriâ€™s killing would not â€œundermine the continued brave resistanceâ€ in Gaza, where the Palestinian groupâ€™s fighters are battling Israeli ground forces. â€œIt proves once more the utter failure of the enemy to achieve any of its aggressive goals in the Gaza Strip,â€ senior Hamas official Izzat al-Rishq said in a statement. The groupâ€™s top leader Ismail Haniyeh condemned the attack as a â€œterrorist actâ€, a violation of Lebanonâ€™s sovereignty, and an expansion of Israelâ€™s circle of hostility against Palestinians. Haniyeh said in televised remarks that Hamas â€œwill never be defeatedâ€. There was no immediate comment from Israel. Mark Regev, an adviser to Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, told the United States news channel MSNBC that Israel had not taken responsibility for the attack but â€œwhoever did it, it must be clear that this was not an attack on the Lebanese stateâ€. â€œWhoever did this did a surgical strike against the Hamas leadership,â€ Regev said in an interview. Lebanese Prime Minister Najib Mikati condemned the killing. His office said in a statement that the attack â€œaims to draw Lebanon into a new phase of confrontationsâ€ with Israel at a time when Hamas ally Hezbollah has been exchanging daily cross-border fire with Israeli forces in northern Israel, the statement said. Al Jazeeraâ€™s Zeina Khodr, reporting from Beirut, said there was â€œpanicâ€ in the Lebanese capital after the attack. â€œThe targeted killing made many people here in the capital feel that this conflict could widen and could escalate, and all eyes are now on Hezbollahâ€™s reaction,â€ Khodr said. Iran, which supports both Hamas and Hezbollah, said al-Arouriâ€™s killing would create more resistance against Israel, its state media reported. â€œThe martyrâ€™s blood will undoubtedly ignite another surge in the veins of resistance and the motivation to fight against the Zionist occupiers not only in Palestine but also in the region and among all freedom seekers worldwide,â€ Iranian Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesperson Nasser Kanaani said. Kanaani also condemned the violation of Lebanonâ€™s sovereignty and territorial integrity. Netanyahu had threatened to kill al-Arouri long before Israelâ€™s latest assault on the besieged Gaza Strip. Israeli political analyst Akiva Eldar told Al Jazeera the killing was a much needed success for Netanyahu.    Imad Harb, director of research at the Arab Center Washington DC, agreed, saying Israel carried out the attack in search for what has become an elusive win. â€œSo far, the Israelis have not been able to call a victory in Gaza, so assassinating Hamas leaders is partly something that they wanted to do anyway,â€ he told Al Jazeera. â€œThis is an achievement for the Israeli army and for the Israeli politicians.â€ Since Israeli forces and Hezbollah began exchanging fire across the Lebanese-Israeli border on October 8, the fighting has largely been concentrated a few kilometres inside each country. But on several occasions, Israelâ€™s air force has hit what it said were Hezbollah positions deeper inside Lebanon. Harb said the killing of al-Arouri is a â€œdangerous escalationâ€ because it took place in Hezbollahâ€™s area of operations, far from the border. Harb predicted Hezbollah would likely step up attacks on Israel in response to the killing but would stop short of escalating the conflict into an all-out war. Meanwhile, at mosques in Arura, the hometown of the slain Hamas leader in the West Bank, Palestinians gathered to mourn al-Arouriâ€™s death. Protests and gatherings also took place in Ramallah and several nearby towns, such as Deir Qaddis. A general strike in Ramallah has also been called for Wednesday.

Title: Israel promises to fight South Africa genocide accusation at ICJ
Subtitle: South Africa launched case against Israel, saying the magnitude of death and destruction in Gaza meets the threshold of the 1948 Genocide Convention.
Content: Israel will appear before the International Court of Justice (ICJ) in The Hague to contest South Africaâ€™s accusation that it is committing genocide against Palestinians in its war with Hamas, an Israeli government spokesman says. South Africalaunched the case against Israel on Friday, saying the magnitude of death, destruction and the extent of the humanitarian crisis in the Gaza Strip meets the threshold of the 1948 Genocide Convention under international law. South Africa also asked the court to order Israel to stop its attacks in Gaza. A spokesperson for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Tuesday accused South Africa of â€œgiving political and legal coverâ€ to the October 7 Hamas attacks on Israel, which triggered the three-month-long war. â€œThe state of Israel will appear before the International Court of Justice at The Hague to dispel South Africaâ€™s absurd blood libel,â€ Eylon Levy said. â€œWe assure South Africaâ€™s leaders, history will judge you, and it will judge you without mercy,â€ Levy added. The spokesperson said Hamas was responsible for the war it started and was â€œwaging from inside and underneath hospitals, schools, mosques, homes and UN facilitiesâ€. For decades, South Africa hasbacked the Palestinian cause for statehood. It has likened the treatment of Palestinians to those of the Black majority in South Africa during the apartheid era, a comparison that Israel vehemently denies. Clayson Monyela, a spokesperson for South Africaâ€™s Department of International Relations and Cooperation, said in a post on X that lawyers representing South Africa were preparing for the hearing scheduled for January 11 and 12. The announcement comes as fierce fighting continues in southern Gaza with Israeli forces bombarding the city of Khan Younis from the air and ground. The Palestinian Red Crescent Society said on Tuesday that Israeli forces hit its headquarters in Khan Younis, resulting in several deaths and injuries among the displaced people who had been sheltering there. The Palestinian Ministry of Health in Gaza said on Tuesday that more than 200 people had been killed in 24 hours, taking the death toll from the Israeli assault on Gaza to more than 22,000.

Title: Israeli army launches attacks on targets in Syria and Lebanon
Subtitle: As war in Gaza rages, Israel is continuing its campaign against Syrian military and Hezbollah targets, sparking fears of regional spillover.
Content: Israel has launched attacks on positions in Syria and Lebanon, as part of its ongoing campaign against opposing militaries and armed forces in the Middle East. â€œThe [Israeli army] struck military infrastructure belonging to the Syrian Army,â€ the Israeli military said in a post on the social media platform X on Tuesday. â€œ[Israeli military] fighter jets also struck Hezbollah terrorist infrastructure in Lebanon,â€ it added, promising it would â€œcontinue to operate against any threat to Israelâ€™s sovereigntyâ€. Israelâ€™s military has been engaged in cross-border fighting with Hezbollah and has launched repeated air raids on Syria since its war on Gaza began on October 7, raising fears of the conflict spilling over into the wider region. In response to yesterday's launches toward Israeli territory, the IDF struck military infrastructure belonging to the Syrian Army. IDF fighter jets also struck Hezbollah terrorist infrastructure in Lebanon. The IDF will continue to operate against any threat to Israel'sâ€¦pic.twitter.com/xSty1eyMkb â€” Israel Defense Forces (@IDF)January 2, 2024  The latest attacks, which occurred between Monday and Tuesday, marked a spike in tensions between Israel and neighbours it has said have links to its enemy, Iran. Earlier on Tuesday, Syrian state news agency SANA said pre-dawn Israeli attacks came from the direction of the Golan Heights. The air raids targeted â€œa number of sites in the Damascus countrysideâ€, SANA reported, citing an unnamed military source as saying only â€œmaterial damageâ€ had been caused. Britain-based war monitor the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights said that one position targeted near the town of Kanaker housed members from Lebanonâ€™s Hezbollah, the AFP news agency reported. Parts of the southern Lebanese city of Yaroun also came under fire, the Israeli military said on Tuesday, after Hezbollah announced it had fired on Israeli units near the northern Israeli village of Sarit. â€œWhat Israel is facing at the moment is fighters in various countries in the region that are mostly backed by Iran,â€ said Al Jazeeraâ€™s Sara Khairat, reporting from Tel Aviv on Tuesday. Syria and Iran are regional allies, with President Bashar al-Assad having received staunch support from Tehran during the war in Syria. Since its formation in 1982, Iran-backed Hezbollah has grown into a powerful â€œstate within a stateâ€ in Lebanon, and has also backed Hamas in Gaza. â€œOf course the biggest threat so far has been from the Iranian-backed group Hezbollah in Lebanon that has been firing every single day,â€ Khairat said. â€œThis is just showing that despite [Israelâ€™s] continued war in Gaza, these attacks are going to continue. â€œCertainly there has been a call amongst those in the [Israeli] military to start to look to redirect their efforts especially along that northern border, with Israel itself saying that if diplomatic efforts donâ€™t work then it wouldnâ€™t be afraid to consider other military action against Lebanon,â€ our correspondent added. Tuesdayâ€™s attacks follow closely on the heels of an Israeli air raid nearAleppoat the end of December, which caused some material damage, according to the Syrian Ministry of Defence. Since the Syrian war began, Israel has launched hundreds of air raids on Syrian territory, both on Syrian military and Hezbollah targets. Israel has repeatedly said it will not allow Iran to expand its presence in Syria. In December, an Israeli air raid outside Damascus killed Razi Moussavi, asenior adviserin Iranâ€™s Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) responsible for coordinating the military alliance between Syria and Iran. Reports from Iranâ€™s news agency INRA said that Mousavi had been part of an entourage accompanying IRGC General Qassem Soleimani at Baghdad airport when he was killed by a US drone attack almost exactly four years ago.

Title: Israel maintains onslaught as Gaza death toll tops 22,000
Subtitle: Gazaâ€™s health ministry says 22,185 Palestinians have now been killed in Gaza since October 7.
Content: Israeli attacks have continued across theGaza Stripwith little let-up, as the death toll in the enclave rose above the latest milestone of 22,000. The total number of Palestinians killed in Gaza since October 7 now stands at 22,185, while at least 57,000 have been injured, the Ministry of Health said on Tuesday. Meanwhile, air and ground attacks continued, including in southern Gaza, where hundreds of thousands of displaced people have been directed to seek safety. And an attack on a Hamas office inLebanonkilled a senior leader of the group the governs the Gaza Strip. Some two-thirds of those killed in Israelâ€™s bombardment of Gaza are women and children, according to the health ministry. Israel launched its campaign following Hamasâ€™s raid into southern Israel, which killed around 1,140 and saw around 240 taken hostage. Overall, 207 Palestinians have been killed in 15 Israeli attacks over the past 24 hours, the health ministry said. It also reported that 338 people were wounded. Al Jazeeraâ€™s Hani Mahmoud, reporting from Khan Younis in the south, said there was â€œintense bombardmentâ€ in the central and southern regions last night and in the early hours of Tuesday morning. â€œThere were reports of massive explosions in these two areas, in Khan Younis and refugee camps in the central part,â€ he said. The intensity of the bombing and the fact that many roads and much infrastructure were destroyed prevented ambulances from going to the targeted sites and taking people to hospitals. The headquarters of the Palestinian Red Crescent Society (PRCS) in Khan Younis was also attacked on Tuesday, the group said, resulting in the deaths of at least five people. â€œThis is the second attack carried out against this institution,â€ Al Jazeeraâ€™s Tareq Abu Azzoum said, speaking from Rafah. In the central Gaza city of Deir el-Balah, Israeli forces hit a home, killing mostly women and children, local Palestinian outlet Wafa News Agency said. In the Nuseirat refugee camp, also in central Gaza, at least one girl was killed and several others injured after an Israeli drone opened fire on the market. â€œThe Israeli military offensive is directed towards the middle governorates, which have been witnessing systematic destruction of residential neighbourhoods,â€ Abu Azzoum said. â€œThey have destroyed dozens of houses today, forcing people to flee towards the southern parts of Gaza.â€ More than one million Palestinians have been displaced from northern Gaza since October 13, when the Israeli military ordered people toevacuateto the south with 24 hours of notice. In central Gazaâ€™s Bureij refugee camp, Hamasâ€™s armed wing, the Qassam Brigades, said it had clashed with Israeli forces in the eastern part of the camp, while also targeting an Israeli Merkava tank. Theal-Quds Brigades, the armed wing of the Islamic Jihad, says that its fighters fought an armed battle with Israeli soldiers in the Bureij refugee camp that resulted in injuries among the soldiers. The armed wing also announced that it targeted the Israeli military with mortar shells in the al-Mahatta area in Khan Younis. The Israeli army said that 31 soldiers have been injured in the Gaza Strip during the past 24 hours. So far, 507 of its soldiers have been killed since the war began. Meanwhile, the Israeli military said it killed Hamas members who were planting mines along Gazaâ€™s coastline and in nearby buildings. The Israeli army said it also killed three Hamas members in an air attack after seeing them enter a building south of Gaza City in the north.    On Tuesday evening, an apparent Israeli attack on a suburb in the Lebanese capital, Beirut,killed senior Hamas officialSaleh al-Arouri and at least five other people. Hamas has vowed that the killing will not â€œundermine the continued brave resistanceâ€ in Gaza. With at least 22,000 Palestinians massacred in Gaza, Israel has lost its â€œcarte blancheâ€ from Western allies, said Adel Abdel Ghafar, a senior fellow at the Middle East Council on Global Affairs. â€œAs scenes of carnage, displaced populations, dead children and starvation fill our screens, the tide is really shifting,â€ he told Al Jazeera, adding thatmassive pro-Palestinian ralliesacross Europe and the United States have exerted pressure on politicians, with some European countries like Belgium changing their tone on Gaza and calling for a ceasefire, something Israel has firmly rejected. â€œItâ€™s also very interesting to keep an eye on US politics given that this is an election year and [US President Joe] Bidenâ€™s ratings are down,â€ said Abdel Ghafar. â€œThis will factor into his calculus in this New Year.â€

Title: Turkey arrests dozens suspected of spying for Israel
Subtitle: Suspects detained in raids for allegedly planning to pursue, assault and kidnap foreign nationals living in Turkey.
Content: Turkey has reportedly detained 33 people suspected of spying on behalf of Israel. The authorities are still searching for 13 other people believed to have links to Israelâ€™s Mossad security service, the Anadolu Agency reported on Tuesday. Ankara has previously warned that it will not allow Israel to strike at Hamas inside Turkeyâ€™s borders. The suspects were detained in raids in Istanbul and seven other provinces for allegedly planning to carry out activities that included â€œreconnaissanceâ€ and â€œpursuing, assaulting and kidnappingâ€ foreign nationals living in Turkey, the agency reported. â€œWe will never allow espionage activities to be conducted against the national unity and solidarity of our country,â€ Interior Minister Ali Yerlikaya said on social media. Anadolu did not provide information on the suspects, nor the foreigners who were allegedly targeted. The report came weeks after the head of Israelâ€™s domestic security agency, Shin Bet, said in an audio recording that his organisation is prepared to destroy Hamas â€œin every place,â€ including in Lebanon, Turkey and Qatar. Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan warned Israel of â€œserious consequencesâ€ if it pressed ahead with its threat to attack Hamas officials on Turkish soil. Following years of tension, Turkey and Israel moved towards normalising ties in 2022 as they resumed diplomatic ties. But that detente quickly deteriorated during the Israel-Hamas war, with Ankara becoming one of the strongest critics of Israelâ€™s military actions in Gaza. Israel initially withdrew its diplomats from Turkey over security concerns and later announced it was recalling its diplomats for political reasons, citing â€œincreasingly harsh statementsâ€ from Turkish officials. Turkey also pulled its ambassador from Israel. Erdoganâ€™s reaction to the Israel-Hamas war was initially fairly muted. But the Turkish leader has sinceintensified his criticism of Israel, describing its actions in Gaza as verging on â€œgenocideâ€. He has called for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to be prosecuted for â€œwar crimesâ€ andcompared him to Nazi leader Adolf Hitler. The Turkish leader, whose government has hosted several Hamas officials in the past, has also said that the Palestinian group â€“ considered a â€œterrorist organisationâ€ by Israel, the United States and the European Union â€“ is fighting for the liberation of its lands and people. The arrests have come amid a spate of arrests by Turkish security forces. In roughly two weeks before the new year, about 500 people suspected of having ties to the ISIL (ISIS) armed group weredetained in raids across the country. The detentions were thought to be part of a drive by Turkeyâ€™s security forces ahead of New Year festivities. An ISIL attack in Istanbul on January 1, 2017,killed 39 people. At the same time, some have also viewed the uptick in arrests as part of a political push in advance of local elections in March. Analysts say that President Erdogan is eager to win back control of Istanbul, Ankara and other major economic hubs that his AK Party has lost.

Title: Whatâ€™s next for Netanyahu after top court ruling against judicial overhaul?
Subtitle: After months of protests, the Supreme Court has nullified a law that aimed to curb its powers and give parliament more sway.
Content: The Israeli Supreme Court has struck down a controversial law that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahuâ€™s coalition government has been pushing for months â€“ but caused uproar and prompted thousands of people to take to the streets in defiant protest. That decision is being seen as a blow to the coalition government which promised to enact sweeping changes that would curb judicial powers but has suffered deep divisions since being sworn in, late in 2022. Those fissures appear to have only deepened, with the top courtâ€™s ruling made as Israel wages a devastating war on Gaza that has already killed more than 22,000 people in the besieged enclave, more than a third of them children. So what is the controversy about â€“ and what is next for Israel and Netanyahu? The law was the only one from a package of judicial overhauls by Netanyahuâ€™s government that aimed to limit the Supreme Courtâ€™s powers concerning the executive. Since Israel does not have a constitution, it relies on a set of Basic Laws and the legislation in question was an amendment to an existing provision that allowed the Supreme Court to overrule laws that, in its view, did not pass a â€œreasonablenessâ€ test. The new law eliminated the top courtâ€™s ability to block laws using that test. Other laws that are part of the planned judicial overhaul would give the Knesset, Israelâ€™s parliament, more power to appoint Supreme Court judges. Before being passed in July, and even after that, the law saw swift and intense opposition in Israel, with thousands of people in Israel and abroad demonstrating for several weeks on end. Thousands of army reservists also threatened to quit. Detractors say the law removes a crucial checks and balances component of Israeli democracy needed in a country with a fragile legal system. Many Israelis also said the amendment weakens the independence of the judiciary at a time when the country is being run by its most far-right and most religiously conservative coalition yet. Western allies, including the United States and the United Kingdom, cautioned Netanyahu and advised his government to â€œuphold democracyâ€Â  as demonstrations raged across the two countries. Although it saw great opposition from inside the Knesset as well, the bill passed with a vote of 64 to 0 after opposition lawmakers boycotted and left the session. In a vote on Monday, 12 of 15 Supreme Court judges ruled for the first time that the court had the power to strike down Basic Laws. Eight judges further voted to nullify this specific â€œreasonablenessâ€ amendment. It is the first time the court will nullify a Basic Law or an amendment to one. In a case summary, the Supreme Court said the governmentâ€™s passing of the law â€œcompletely revoked the possibility of carrying out judicial review of the reasonableness of decisions made by the government, the prime minister, and the ministers,â€ and added that letting the law stand could cause â€œunprecedented and severe harmâ€ to Israelâ€™s democracy. Netanyahuâ€™s government has always claimed the law is needed to create balance in government branches and to diversify the bench which it sees as putting minority interests before national ones. But some see the push for the law as an attempt by Netanyahu to avoid sentencing in a drawn-out corruption trial in which he faces charges of bribery, fraud and breach of trust. Those proceedings were suspended following the start of Israelâ€™s war on Gaza, but resumed early in December. Netanyahu has denied any wrongdoing. Netanyahuâ€™s Minister of Justice Yariv Levin, who has shepherded the controversial laws, including the one that the court has struck down, hit out at the judges, insisting that the ruling would not â€œstay our handâ€. Levin also said that the decision by the court to publish its ruling while Israelâ€™s war on Gaza was continuing is â€œthe opposite of the unity required these days for the success of our fighters on the front.â€ Likud, Netanyahuâ€™s party, said the decision was â€œunfortunateâ€. Yet, if the government decides to ignore the Supreme Court ruling, it could end up destabilising the wartime coalition that is leading Israelâ€™s assault on Gaza. Minister of Defense Yoav Gallant has opposed the amendment â€“ and was even temporarily fired over it. On Monday, former defense minister Benny Gantz also called for the Supreme Court ruling to be respected â€“ effectively publicly rejecting Levinâ€™s criticism of the judges. ×¢×¨×‘ ×”-7.10 ×”×—×‘×¨×” ×”×™×©×¨××œ×™×ª ×”×’×™×¢×” ×œ××§×•××•×ª ×§×™×¦×•× ×™×™×, ×œ×¤×™×œ×•×’ ×•×œ×©×™×— ×©× ××” ×©×”×™×” ××¡×•×¨ ×œ×”×’×™×¢ ××œ×™×”×. ××ª ×¤×¡×§ ×”×“×™×Ÿ ×—×•×‘×” ×œ×›×‘×“, ×•××ª ×”×œ×§×— ××”×”×ª× ×”×œ×•×ª ×‘×©× ×” ×”××—×¨×•× ×” ×—×•×‘×” ×œ×”×¤× ×™× â€“ ××—×™× ×× ×—× ×•, ×œ×›×•×œ× ×• ×’×•×¨×œ ××©×•×ª×£. ××œ×• ×œ× ×™××™× ×œ× ×™×’×•×—×™× ×¤×•×œ×™×˜×™×™×, ××™×Ÿ ×”×™×•× ×× ×¦×—×™× ×•××¤×¡×™×“×™×. ×”×™×•× ×™×© ×œ× ×• ×¨×§ ××˜×¨×” ××—×ª ××©×•×ª×¤×ªâ€¦ â€” ×‘× ×™ ×’× ×¥ â€“ Benny Gantz (@gantzbe)January 1, 2024  â€œThe verdict must be respected, and the lesson from the conduct of the last year must be internalised â€“ we are brothers, we all have a common destiny,â€ he wrote on X. â€œThese are not days for political arguments, there are no winners and losers today. Today we have only one common goal â€“ to win the war, together.â€

Title: Israeli raids kill five as lethal operations persist in occupied West Bank
Subtitle: The Israeli military says four Palestinians were killed in Azzun, while a fifth was shot dead in Qalqilya.
Content: At least five Palestinians have been killed during overnight raids in the occupied West Bank, the Israeli military has said. Four Palestinians were killed in Azzun, while the fifth was shot dead in Qalqilya after allegedly opening fire during a raid, the military said on Tuesday. Casualties and arrests have been rife in the West Bank amid increased activity by Israel amid its war in Gaza. Detailing the latest incidents, the Israeli army posted a photo of three Carlo sub-machine guns they claimed the four men were carrying. The Palestine Ministry of Health also confirmed the deaths in Azzun on their Telegram channel, adding that the bodies of the deceased were taken away by Israeli forces. There was no immediate comment from Palestinian officials on the person killed in Qalqilya. Since the Hamas offensive on October 7, Israeli forces have intensifiedlethal operationsthroughout the occupied West Bank, resulting in more than 320 Palestinian deaths from military actions and settler attacks. Close to 5,000 people have been arrested in the territory since the Israel-Hamas war in Gaza began. Al Jazeeraâ€™s Bernard Smith, reporting from Ramallah, said there were at least a dozen raids in the West Bank overnight. Azzun was the most serious, he added. â€œWe know there have been violent confrontations between Palestinians and Israeli security forces there. An IED was thrown at a military Jeep,â€ he said. The bodies of the four people killed were taken away by Israeli forces, Smith said, noting that such action is â€œnot unusualâ€. â€œSince October 7, 46 bodies have been withheld by the Israelis and they got 194 in total since 2016,â€ he added. Raids also took place in the city of Jenin, Smith reported. â€œThose raids are happening practically every night in Jenin, a centre of Palestinian resistance.â€ The United Nations in a report last weekurgedIsrael to cease â€œunlawful killingsâ€ and settler violence in the occupied West Bank. The UN Human Rights Office highlighted a concerning escalation in air raids and military incursions into densely populated refugee camps last week, leading to casualties and extensive damage to civilian infrastructure in the occupied territory.

Title: Sudanâ€™s feared paramilitary leader signals ambition to rule the country
Subtitle: Mohamed Hamdan â€˜Hemedtiâ€™ Dagalo goes on an African tour to secure regional support and political legitimacy.
Content: When Sudanâ€™s civil war erupted in April between the army and the Rapid Support Forces (RSF), the paramilitary groupâ€™s leader, Mohamed Hamdan â€œHemedtiâ€ Dagalo, went into hiding. Many speculated he had been seriously wounded or was even dead until he appeared in a photo-op with Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni on Wednesday. The next day, Hemedti visited Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed, ostensibly to discuss strategies to end Sudanâ€™s conflict. He also passed through Ghana and Djibouti. UPDATE-  President Museveni, has met with Gen. Mohamed Hamdan Dagalo, the former Deputy Chair of the Transitional Sovereignty Council of Sudan, at his country home in Rwakitura. They discussed, among other things, ways to put an end to the continued conflict in Sudan.#UBCNEWSpic.twitter.com/HxFzdIN0t5 â€” UBC UGANDA (@ubctvuganda)December 27, 2023  Analysts believe Hemedtiâ€™s real motive was securing regional support to capture all of Sudan from the army. Last month, the RSF captured Gezira state â€“ a breadbasket for Sudan â€“ giving the group the clear upper hand against the army. But rather than leverage military success in negotiations to end the conflict, Hemedti appears to have ambitions to rule all of Sudan, according to analysts, Sudanese journalists and diplomats. â€œHemedti desperately needs people to feel that the RSF is a governing force. I think this is why Hemedti went to meet heads of state,â€ said Kholood Khair, a Sudan expert and founding director of the think tank Confluence Advisory. â€œHemedti will try as much as possible to fashion himself into this idea of being a leader,â€ Khair told Al Jazeera. On December 9, the Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD), an eight-nation East African bloc,releaseda statement saying Hemedti and army chief Abdel Fattah al-Burhan would meet face to face in two weeks. But Hemedti went to Uganda the day before he was supposed to meet al-Burhan for ceasefire talks in Djibouti.Â IGAD postponed the talks for â€œtechnical reasonsâ€. On Monday, Hemedti met with Sudanâ€™s former prime minister and the leader of a newlyformedcivilian bloc, the Coordination of Civil Democratic Forces (Taqaddum), Abdallah Hamdok, in Ethiopia. Taqaddum has announced it also invited al-Burhan to meet at another date, but there has been no information about whether that invitation has been accepted. Khair believes Hemedti and al-Burhan are both partaking in â€“ and derailing â€“ mediation efforts to buy time for their military operations. â€œThis is all a red herring â€¦ to gain some international kudos while at the same time trying to gain some ground [in the war],â€ she told Al Jazeera. In October, the RSF captured several army garrisons across the sprawling western region of Darfur, just as the US-backed mediation talks in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, were about to resume after a lengthy hiatus. Jonas Horner, an independent expert on Sudan, told Al Jazeera the RSFâ€™s expansion as it takes more states to the north and east is not sustainable. He noted that the paramilitary has recruited heavily from its tribal base in Darfur in exchange for allowing the fighters to loot cities they capture. But the pillaging of homes, hospitals, United Nations warehouses and markets has led to popular resentment and hatred of the group, he said. â€œ[The RSFâ€™s] atrocities and their hardcore cruelty â€¦ is probably their single biggest obstacle and makes the prospect of them governing the country far more difficult,â€ Horner said. â€œI think so many Sudanese â€¦ are never going to be comfortable with the RSF governing them,â€ he added. Despite committing a myriad of human rights abuses, the RSF is trying to bring law and order to regions under its control, Sudanese journalist Mohamad el-Fatih Yousif said from Darfur. He told Al Jazeera that the paramilitary has created a department called Civil and Political Management, whose paid employees are responsible for repairing basic services like hospitals, electricity grids and water stations in South Darfurâ€™s capital, Nyala. â€œThere is relative safety right now in Nyala,â€ el-Fatih Yousif said. â€œAll the RSF fighters that were looting Nyala left. They all went to Gezira state.â€ The RSF has alsoestablisheda local police force in Sudanâ€™s capital, Khartoum, most of which it controls. Police forces have also been instructed to maintain order throughout Darfur. Many activists and analysts are mocking the groupâ€™s ostensible attempt to combat criminality and blame the RSF for most of the theft, violence and lawlessness in the country. This is a farce. Will the RSF's police force arrest RSF forces for the killing, looting, property destruction, occupation of houses, sexual violence, and other crimes in which they've been implicated in Khartoum and other areas?https://t.co/0iM6rcOFQF â€” Lauren Blanchard (@LaurenBinDC)December 13, 2023  â€œThis is a farce,â€ tweeted Lauren Blanchard, an expert on Sudan and a specialist in African affairs at the Congressional Research Service. â€œWill the RSFâ€™s police force arrest RSF forces for the killing, looting, property destruction, occupation of houses, sexual violence, and other crimes in which they have been implicated in Khartoum and other areas?â€ While almost nobody in northern and eastern Sudan will accept living under Hemedti, European countries will cooperate with the RSF if it captures the entire country, according to one Western diplomat who spoke to Al Jazeera on the condition of anonymity. He said that in the interest of stemming migration from Africa to Europe, the European Union is already signing partnerships with strongman leaders such as Tunisian President Kais Said and an eastern Libyan militia connected to renegade military commander Khalifa Haftar. The EU also previously worked with the RSF on migration as part of the Khartoum Process, a 2014 migration pact between the EU and countries in the Horn of Africa to combat the trafficking and smuggling of human beings. The EU suspended cooperation with Sudan after the RSF spearheaded an attack on a sit-in on June 3, 2019, according to open-source investigations carried out by human rights groups. At least 120 people were killed in what survivors and rights groups called a massacre. â€œEurope denied that they ever supported the RSF directly, but they did. And I think that they will do so in the future if that is what is necessary,â€ the diplomat told Al Jazeera. â€œAnd if it turns out that the RSF is about to take over all of Sudan, then I think the EU will make the calculation that they have to publicly condemn what the RSF is doing. â€œBut I donâ€™t think [the EU] will stop the RSF or support any country to stop the RSF from taking over the country.â€
